dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2020, the pandemic really forced European policymakers to walk this tightrope—like, how do you support incomes without triggering hyperinflation or deflation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty, the pandemic really forced European policymakers to walk this tightrope-like, how do you support incomes without triggering hyperinflation or deflation?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The COVID-19 pandemic created both a short- and a medium-term challenge for American economic policy. The immediate challenge was to maintain consumers incomes in the face of sweeping lockdowns, supply-chain disruptions, and shifts in aggregate supply.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that medium-term structural shift was huge, right? People stopped buying so many durable goods and moved toward services, especially digital ones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that medium-term structural shift was huge, right? People stopped buying so many durable goods and moved toward services, especially digital ones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge concerned a broader crisis-induced structural shift away from the purchase of services especially in-person services toward the purchase of durable goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And now, services spending is up 38% since 2018, while durables are only 15% higher. That's a massive gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And now, services spending is up thirty eight percent since twenty eighteen, while durables are only fifteen percent higher. That's a massive gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, durable-goods spending in real terms is 38% above where it was at the end of March 2018, while services spending is only 15% higher, a 23-percentage-point gap in relative growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which meant they had to incentivize workers and firms to adapt, but without just raising wages in shrinking sectors. Tricky stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which meant they had to incentivize workers and firms to adapt, but without just raising wages in shrinking sectors. Tricky stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge, then, was to create the market incentives to induce workers and firms to respond to this great structural shift in demand. Since neither nominal wages nor prices were going to fall back to their previous levels (they are sticky, in the economic parlance), substantially cutting wages and prices in shrinking service-sector industries was a non-starter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then the recent employment numbers… September payrolls revised down by 22,000, plus another 25,000 drop in October? That's 47,000 fewer jobs than we thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the recent employment numbers... September payrolls revised down by twenty two thousand, plus another twenty five thousand drop in October? That's forty seven thousand fewer jobs than we thought.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 4, we learned that estimated payroll employment (seasonally adjusted) in September was 254,000 higher than it had been in August. Moreover, the August number was revised upward by 72,000, which means there are 326,000 more employed workers than in the previous jobs report.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Unemployment's back up to 5.1% too, after hitting 3.3% in July. Just one data point, but still—wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unemployment's back up to five point one percent too, after hitting three point three percent in July. Just one data point, but still-wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After rising from 3.8% a year ago to 4.3% in July, the unemployment rate is back down to 4.1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And real income growth was revised down by 6.6% for Q2 2023. Productivity estimates took a hit as well.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And real income growth was revised down by six point six percent for Q2 twenty twenty three. Productivity estimates took a hit as well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Real (inflation-adjusted) income as of the second quarter of 2024 has been revised upward by 3.6%, and the estimated level of real production which by definition should be equal to real income, save for a pesky statistical discrepancy was revised upward by 1.3%. This means that estimated productivity growth since the start of 2020 will be revised upward by about 0.3 percentage points per year, whereas real labor costs will be revised downward by a similar amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So all that stimulus and support might've been less effective than we assumed. Makes you rethink the whole recovery narrative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So all that stimulus and support might've been less effective than we assumed. Makes you rethink the whole recovery narrative.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Bank of England's loosening cycle had me worried they'd overdo it and cause a recession… and now it looks like maybe they did?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Bank of England's loosening cycle had me worried they'd overdo it and cause a recession... and now it looks like maybe they did?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the US Federal Reserve began its rapid tightening cycle in the spring of 2022, I was constantly worried that it would go too far and send the US economy into an unnecessary and avoidable recession. But there has been no recession, and now I have to think hard about why I was wrong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Or maybe the neutral interest rate fell more than anyone expected, so policy was tighter than intended. Hard to say.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or maybe the neutral interest rate fell more than anyone expected, so policy was tighter than intended. Hard to say.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Or is it because the neutral rate of interest has risen substantially over the past half-decade, implying that the Feds monetary policy has been substantially less restrictive and contractionary than I thought?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's AI—everyone's excited, but will it actually boost profits or just turn out to be another bubble?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's A I-everyone's excited, but will it actually boost profits or just turn out to be another bubble?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One obvious risk is that the ongoing AI boom will prove to be a bubble. While there are plenty of promising use cases for AI technologies, it is not yet clear how these will translate into increased business profits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Macro forecasting usually favors optimists, but this soft landing… I don't know if it feels like much of a landing at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Macro forecasting usually favors optimists, but this soft landing... I don't know if it feels like much of a landing at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Macroeconomic forecasting often rewards pessimists. For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right. The recovery's been pretty disappointing overall. Not a lot of silver linings here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. The recovery's been pretty disappointing overall. Not a lot of silver linings here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The post-pandemic economy has had no shortage of silver linings. The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: At least we're talking about it. Maybe that's step one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: At least we're talking about it. Maybe that's step one.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2020, the pandemic really forced European policymakers to walk this tightrope—like, how do you support incomes without triggering hyperinflation or deflation?
HostB: Yeah, and that medium-term structural shift was huge, right? People stopped buying so many durable goods and moved toward services, especially digital ones.
HostA: Exactly. And now, services spending is up 38% since 2018, while durables are only 15% higher. That’s a massive gap.
HostB: Which meant they had to incentivize workers and firms to adapt, but without just raising wages in shrinking sectors. Tricky stuff.
HostA: And then the recent employment numbers… September payrolls revised down by 22,000, plus another 25,000 drop in October? That’s 47,000 fewer jobs than we thought.
HostB: Unemployment’s back up to 5.1% too, after hitting 3.3% in July. Just one data point, but still—wow.
HostA: And real income growth was revised down by 6.6% for Q2 2023. Productivity estimates took a hit as well.
HostB: So all that stimulus and support might’ve been less effective than we assumed. Makes you rethink the whole recovery narrative.
HostA: The Bank of England’s loosening cycle had me worried they’d overdo it and cause a recession… and now it looks like maybe they did?
HostB: Or maybe the neutral interest rate fell more than anyone expected, so policy was tighter than intended. Hard to say.
HostA: And then there’s AI—everyone’s excited, but will it actually boost profits or just turn out to be another bubble?
HostB: Macro forecasting usually favors optimists, but this soft landing… I don’t know if it feels like much of a landing at all.
HostA: Right. The recovery’s been pretty disappointing overall. Not a lot of silver linings here.
HostB: At least we’re talking about it. Maybe that’s step one.
